prompt: We have one space per team. I want all teams to be able to view all spaces but each team should only be able to edit their own space. How can I configure this in XWiki?
expected_answer:
To achieve the desired access control, you can follow these steps:

1. **Create groups for each team**: Create a separate group for each team in your XWiki instance. This will allow you to manage access rights for each team individually.
2. **Set wiki-wide rights**: Go to the wiki administration page and set the rights for the entire wiki. Specifically, set the "View" right to "Allow" for "XWikiAllGroup" to allow everyone to view all spaces.
3. **Set space-level rights**: For each team's space, go to the space administration page and set the rights for that space. Specifically, set the "Edit" right to "Allow" only for the corresponding team's group. This will allow only the members of that team to edit their own space.
4. **Inherit rights for child pages**: When setting rights for a space, make sure to select the "Rights: Page & Children" option to inherit the rights for all child pages within that space.

By following these steps, you'll ensure that:

* All teams can view all spaces.
* Each team can only edit their own space.

Remember to adjust the rights accordingly for any additional teams or spaces you may have in your XWiki instance.

To achieve this configuration in XWiki, follow these steps:

### Step 1: Create a group for each team

*   Go to **Wiki Administration** > **Users & Groups**.
*   Create a new group for each team (e.g., `Team A`, `Team B`, `Team C`, etc.).

### Step 2: Assign users to their respective teams

*   Add users to their respective teams by selecting the user and clicking on the "Add to Group" button.

### Step 3: Set view rights for all teams at the wiki level

*   Go to **Wiki Administration** > **Rights**.
*   Select the **Wiki** scope.
*   Click on the "Add Rights" button and choose the `View` right.
*   In the "User/Group" field, select the group `XWikiAllGroup` to give view rights to all users.
*   Click "Save" to save the changes.

### Step 4: Set edit rights for each team at the space level

*   Go to the **Space Administration** for each team's space.
*   Select the **Rights** section.
*   Click on the "Add Rights" button and choose the `Edit` right.
*   In the "User/Group" field, select the group corresponding to the team that should edit the space.
*   Set the scope to "Space" (not "Wiki") to limit the edit right to the current space.
*   Click "Save" to save the changes.

### Example Rights Configuration:

*   **Wiki Administration** > **Rights**: `XWikiAllGroup` has `View` right ( Wiki scope).
*   **Space Administration** for **Team A** > **Rights**: `Team A` group has `Edit` right (Space scope).
*   **Space Administration** for **Team B** > **Rights**: `Team B` group has `Edit` right (Space scope).

By following these steps, you have configured XWiki so that:

*   All teams can view all spaces.
*   Each team can only edit their own space.

Test this configuration to ensure that the desired rights are being enforced correctly.

sources.content:
Every time a user creates a page from the XWiki UI, he now actually creates a space (without knowing it ![emoticon_wink](https://www.xwiki.org/xwiki/resources/icons/silk/emoticon_wink.png?cache-version=1711538036000)) with its WebHome page. It means that all user-created page are called WebHome. 

Then, when the user wants to create a sub-page, for example FrankCapra inside the page Directors.WebHome, he actually creates a new space inside the space Directors with its WebHome page: Directors.FrankCapra.WebHome. That's how we emulate it.

The notion of space has been removed from the UI. It's not mentioned anywhere, anymore. Everything seems to work as if we were really creating sub-pages, even if under the hood, we create sub-spaces.

That emulation should be temporary. At some point we'd like to refactor the core model of XWiki and discard the concept of spaces to only keep pages. Don't hold your breath though, this may be several years in the coming ![emoticon_wink](https://www.xwiki.org/xwiki/resources/icons/silk/emoticon_wink.png?cache-version=1711538036000)

Note that users still have the ability to create pages that are not named WebHome. As a consequence, such pages (that are not the "WebHome" of their space) cannot have sub-pages. They're called **Terminal Pages**.

XWiki provides a powerful and granular permission system allowing you to control precisely what [user and groups](https://www.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/Documentation/UserGuide/Features/UsersAndGroupsManagement) can do in the wiki.

It offers various rights that can be set (or denied), such as the "View" right (ability to view pages), "Edit" right (ability to edit page content), "Delete" right (ability to delete pages) or "Administer" right (ability to administer pages or the wiki), just to name a few. These rights can be set at different levels: for the whole wiki or for a given space and its children.

If needed, it's even possible to write some [script](https://www.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/Documentation/DevGuide/Scripting) to control programmatically exactly what users are allowed to do.

*Example of the rights UI*  
![GroupRights.png](https://www.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/download/Documentation/UserGuide/Features/RightsManagement/GroupRights.png?rev=1.1)

To learn how to set up permissions, check the [Rights documentation in the Admin Guide](https://www.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/Documentation/AdminGuide/Access%20Rights/).

### Execute the plan

When you are ready, you can execute the plan.

![PlanExecuting.png](https://www.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/download/Documentation/UserGuide/Features/ContentOrganization/NestedPagesMigration/WebHome/PlanExecuting.png?rev=1.1)

* Be patient. The process could be very long. It will use a lot of server resources, so we recommend to don't let users access the wiki during the process. (For example, you can temporary forbid remote connections to your servlet container and access XWiki through an SSH tunnel for yourself.)
* Since all logs are displayed in the page, even the browser can became slow. Note that we have experienced better performances using Chrome instead of Firefox.
* Some OutOfMemory errors could happen. To avoid them, we recommend to give a lot of memory to your XWiki instance during the execution of the migration.
* To minimize migration time, we recommend that you ensure that the Solr queue is empty before starting the migration. You can check Solr queue on the Wiki administration>>Solr Search Section, see [documentation](https://extensions.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/Extension/Solr%20Search%20Application#HSearchAdministrationSection).
**We highly recommend to perform migration tests on a staging server before doing it on a production instance.**

# XWiki Standard Features

[XWiki Standard](http://extensions.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/Extension/XWiki%20Standard%20Flavor/) is the [Flavor](https://www.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/Documentation/UserGuide/Features/Applications#HFlavors) developed by the XWiki Dev Team. It contains the following features (in addition to the base features listed above), which are [Extensions](https://www.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/Documentation/UserGuide/Features/Applications#HExtensions) installed by default.

![photos](https://www.xwiki.org/xwiki/resources/icons/silk/photos.png?cache-version=1711538036000)

![color_swatch](https://www.xwiki.org/xwiki/resources/icons/silk/color_swatch.png?cache-version=1711538036000)

# Basic rules

* XWiki provides the ability to set wiki wide rights, granular page level rights and the ability to have programmatic rights, in case you need more control. Thanks to the different levels of control offered by XWiki, it's easy to manage the access to actions like: read, edit, comment etc.
* You can create groups of users in order to manage the rights of a category of people more easily.
* Permissions set at a wiki wide level will be overridden by permissions set at a page level, which have priority.
* When multiple permissions are set at the same wiki/page level, check the priority order of the right in [permission type](https://www.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/Documentation/AdminGuide/Permission%20types/) to know if access will be allowed or denied.
* When a right has been allowed at a given level, it gets implicitly denied to anyone else at the same level. This only applies to the right allowed. If only "View" is set to a user/group at this level, all other rights like "Edit" are still inherited. Using this implicit deny behavior is recommended over applying explicit denial.
* The scope of the right applied ("Page" or "Page & Children") affects the implicit denial. If the right is applied for the page only, pages below the current page will still inherit the wiki/higher level pages rights.
* Implied permissions like VIEW of the EDIT right are not implicitly denied when EDIT is set. User/Groups with the VIEW right are still inherited if the page has EDIT explicitly set for a User/Group.
* On the contrary, an explicit denial does not block inheritance for the right denied.
